content.title: Components
content.text:
<section>

In the Components section you can see the building blocks of the Scania Digital Design System for building user interfaces aliged with the Scania Brand. 
Each Component provides different solution to a UI problem and are presented with a visual example together with their specific usage guideline and code example.

</section>

template.title: List subpages
template.text:
Overview

{{sub.title}}

content.title: Button Primary
content.text:
<button type='button' class='btn btn-primary'>Primary</button>
-
<button type='button' class='btn btn-primary' disabled>Primary</button>

content.title: Buttons
content.text:
Buttons are a mode for inputting user action for communicating user’s intention.

Buttons are not the same as links – links are not input modes but it is a mode for navigation – from one page to another page or from one view to another view.
**Example**
**Types of Buttons** - **Solid button**: meant for primary action, solid filled to attract user’s attention - **Outline button**: meant for secondary action and to compliment primary action - **Flat button**: meant for tertiary action - **Disabled button**: meant to prevent users from sending inputs accidently, also meant to prevent input till conditions for the input are met. - **Ellipsis button**: meant for indicating that several tasks are available for users to take action
**Usage Pattern** Two distinct patterns can be used to place buttons ![text](https://sdds-cms.s3.amazonaws.com/be1d256a05024ad98ce2143b6fc6486d.PNG) **Z Pattern** The Z pattern is one of the more common trajectories followed by users when going through the content. For this reason, the core of the content is positioned at the top left side and the call for action is located on the right bottom side. This pattern holds true for languages that are read from left to right. The patterns works in the reverse manner for the languages that are read from right to left. **F pattern** The F pattern is a variation of Z pattern where the core of the content is situated on the left top and the call for action is located on the left bottom. The pattern is reversed for languages that are read from right to left. **Interaction Pattern** Buttons to simulate clicking action that is visualised by means of change in colour/shade **Compositional Pattern (with Style Guide)** Style of buttons to follow the style guide in the following manner - The text inside of buttons to be always UPPERCASE. Descriptive language relating to the intent of the user should be used to formulate button text. *Colour* Primary colour to provide consistency across all applications - **Scania Blue** Action based colour to provide an all clear message or a warning to the user - **green or red** Disabled button colour – **grey** *Icons* Icons – that clearly communicate the intent for action – can be used in place of text for a button When icons are accompanied with text, it follows the icon (i.e. icon first and then the text) Title attribute – a tooltip to be visible when hovering a button (where necessary). The text is displayed below the button. Icons can be used with any kind of buttons mentioned above.

Scania Digital Design System

Digital design standards and resources that enable designers and developers to deliver a premium brand experience.

Download Adobe XD UI Kit

Github for Developers

content.title: Dropdown
content.text:
A dropdown is a type of menu that presents a list of option to the user and allows them to choose one of more to take action

**Example**
Action Another action Something else here
Separated link
**Usage Pattern** - Use a button to toggle the menu. The button can be labelled with text or an icon that is easy to understand. - Menu items to be ordered by usage - make sure that the text is short and concise. Long menus are truncated with ellipsis added - Nested menus can be used when necessary – up to three levels. - disable menu(s) if needed

content.title: List groups
content.text:
Lists or List group are continuous vertical group of links constituting of text and/or images.

**Example**
  • Cras justo odio
  • Dapibus ac facilisis in
  • Morbi leo risus
  • Porta ac consectetur ac
  • Vestibulum at eros
**Usage Pattern** - List groups should be organised in a logical manner that makes it easy to scan and understand, i.e. alphabetical, numerical etc. or by user/use preference. - Listgroups should make it possible for users to take action. - List groups should use text and images and a consistent manner. - List groups can be expanded and collapsed as required.

content.title: Contribution
content.text: Would you like to contribute to the contents of the Scania Digital Design System? If so, you are more than welcome to reach out to us in our [Teams](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/team/19%3a1257007a64d44c64954acca27a9d4b46%40thread.skype/conversations?groupId=79f9bfeb-73e2-424d-9477-b236191ece5e&tenantId=3bc062e4-ac9d-4c17-b4dd-3aad637ff1ac) or directly to [Marcus Åström](mailto:marcus.astrom@scania.com) .

content.title: Cards
content.text:
A card presents content and actions on a single topic.

**Example**
Card title

Some quick example text to build on the card title and make up the bulk of the card's content.

Go somewhere
**Usage Pattern** - Easy to understand content about a topic - Consider cards as an entry point to more details - Keep the content simple and easy to understand - Not all cards are to be clickable. When a card is clickable, the resulting action should be an expected outcome – to navigate to more details for example. ![text](https://sdds-cms.s3.amazonaws.com/c905d0745db748d09041fcc56998f4e7.PNG) **Do** - Use F pattern with call for action on the left bottom side **Don’t** - Use Z pattern with call of action on the right bottom side.

content.title: Support
content.text:
Do you need help within development or with Components? Please reach out in [Teams](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/team/19%3a1257007a64d44c64954acca27a9d4b46%40thread.skype/conversations?groupId=79f9bfeb-73e2-424d-9477-b236191ece5e&tenantId=3bc062e4-ac9d-4c17-b4dd-3aad637ff1ac) or report a [bug](https://github.com/scania/corporate-ui/issues/new/choose) or a [Feature request](https://github.com/scania/corporate-ui/issues/new?assignees=&labels=Feature&template=feature_request.md&title=Feature+-+%22title+text%22) in our Development GitHub.

Need help within the design area? We can't design your application for you but we'll happily guide you through how you can use the different sections and tools in the Scania Digital Design System. Please get in touch with us through [Teams](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/team/19%3a1257007a64d44c64954acca27a9d4b46%40thread.skype/conversations?groupId=79f9bfeb-73e2-424d-9477-b236191ece5e&tenantId=3bc062e4-ac9d-4c17-b4dd-3aad637ff1ac) and we'll do our best to help out.

content.title: Forms
content.text:
Forms is a modality of collecting inputs from the user and submitting it to an application.

**Example**
We'll never share your email with anyone else.
**Usage Pattern** - Forms are constituted of text and input elements such as, checkboxes, dropdowns, radio buttons, toggle switches etc. Forms should be clear and concise to make it easy for users to complete forms. - Use one column to organise the form. - Group input elements that are similar. This makes it easy for users to scan them. - Forms should not be longer than a page – ideally. However, if a forms need to be longer, use pagination. - Forms must let users know when something is wrong with the information provided. Error message styling, content and location should make it easy for users to understand where they have made errors (exact styling to be decided). - Both real-time as well as after post validation can be done as appropriate.

content.text: We'll never share your email with anyone else.

content.title: Design Patterns
content.text:
Design patterns are __templates of recurring solutions__ that solve common design problems. Design patterns can be of two types:

A.	**Compositional design patterns**
B.	**Interaction design pattern**
C.	**Usage pattern**

A.	**Compositional design patterns**

Composition here refers to coming together of, one, UI elements and Style guide elements (such as button with typography or an image) and two, combination of two or more such micro level compositions into a larger whole (i.e. from atoms to molecules to organisms). Such compositions can vary from, for example, a page on the higher side of complexity to a button on the lower side of complexity. 

Compositional design patterns, then, provide templates of recurring solutions to such common compositional problems.

Included in the Scania Design System so far (first version) are compositional design patterns associated with UI elements. These design patterns are part of usage guidelines for the following UI elements (first version).

Alert, Badge, Breadcrumbs, Button, Button group, Cards, Dropdown, Forms, Input groups, List groups, Loading, Media Objects, Modals, Navs, Pagination, Progress, Tables

B.	**Interaction Design patterns**

Interaction refers to the interaction between the user and the user interface. Interaction is constituted of action from the user’s side and the response or feedback from the system’s side. Both, i.e. action from user’s side and the response or feedback from the system’s side are externalised by behaviour of UI elements as well as the compositional elements.

Interaction design patterns, then, provide templates for recurring solutions to user/human computer interaction pertaining to behaviour of UI elements and components that solve common interaction problems.

Example – 

a.	*Interaction design pattern for Buttons (accompanied with animation)*

Toggle buttons

a.	*Interaction with mouse*

When interacted with mouse, button appears to be pressed down – visually – and the interaction is accompanied by a sound (this can vary from case to case basis). The pressed down state of the button is articulated by active colour. This interaction pattern repeats itself when user interacts with the button again to toggle the button off.

b.	*Interaction with touchscreen/touchpad*

When tapped, the button appears to be pressed down – visually – and the interaction is accompanied by a sound (this can vary from case to case basis). The pressed down state of the button is articulated by active colour. This interaction pattern repeats itself when user interacts with the button again to toggle the button off.

C.	**Usage patterns**

Usage patterns refer to template of recurring solution with respect to use of a UI element or a compositional element. The usage pattern is also extended to common functional features, e.g. copy, edit, save, delete etc.

content.title: Input groups
content.text:
Input groups are used to extend input elements (such as radio buttons, check boxes etc.) within a form.

**Example**
@
**Usage Pattern** Follow usage pattern of input groups for individual input elements. Usage pattern for compositions to be added.

content.title: About SDDS
content.text:
The Scania Digital Design System is the single source of truth to be used as a resource for conceptualization and realization of digital design and development projects/initiatives across all of Scania. It consists of information that would be valuable for managers, designers and as well developers who are involved in planning, designing and development of degital design projects/initiatives with the purpose to bring in sustained optimal velocity in implementation and consistency across all kinds of digital solutions.

We look forward to your feedback!

content.title: Getting Started
content.text: Coming soon!

content.title: Modals
content.text:
Modals assist users in completing a task that requires an action by the user.

**Example**
Modal title

Modal body text goes here.

**Usage Pattern** - Focus – modals requires user’s full attention and therefore, the focus needs to shift to the modal to enable user interaction. - Users need to take action about a modal – either to take action or to cancel/dismiss it - Models should not launch other modals - do not use scrolling with a modal as far as possible ![text](https://sdds-cms.s3.amazonaws.com/27b6085ba7de45bc863a0f398be97afc.PNG) Title – title of the Modal to summarise its purpose Content – what the user should focus on? provide a clear and concise explanation Buttons – Use Z pattern with call for action located on the bottom right side.

Modal body text goes here.

content.title: Navs
content.text:
Navigation panel is a collection of links – organized in a horizontal or vertical manner.

**Example**
  • Active
  • Link
  • Link
  • Disabled
**Usage Pattern** Navs or navigational links/buttons must be clearly visible at all times to the users.

content.title: Pagination
content.text:
Pagination is a collection of links that allows users to navigated between pages.

**Example**
  • Previous
  • 1
  • 2
  • 3
  • Next
**Usage Pattern** - Pagination must makes clear to the user the page they are on currently and the options or navigating to other pages (both before the page or after the pages) is clearly visible to them. - User roman numerals to indicate pages. - When working with high number of pages, links to go forward and backward along with links for first and last page to be shown.

content.title: Progress indicators
content.text:
Progress (bar or another form) is used to depict progress of a task e.g. downloading content.

**Example**
**Usage Pattern** - Progress element need to convey the time – the time required for the task to be finished. - Progress elements need to be animated to convey the sense of progress.

content.title: Progress indicator multiple
Tables
content.text:
Tables are used to present static or dynamic data in a tabular (row and column) form.

**Example**
# First Last Handle
1 Mark Otto @mdo
2 Jacob Thornton @fat
3 Larry the Bird @twitter
**Usage Pattern** - the table should organize the content in a meaningful way, e.g. alphabetically for example - Tables may allow users to interact with it where necessary - Table should be intuitive – easy top scan and understand

content.title: Definitions
content.text:
<section>

## Design

Design involves solving a problem by proposing a solution
</section>

<section>

## Solution

A "solution" is a product or combination of products or a service that is customized for solving a problem from a user’s perspective

**Product**

A product is a system of physical and/or digital components that is customized for      user’s needs

**Service**

A service is a system of people, processes, and products that is customized for user’s needs

</section>

<section>

## Human Centered Design (from ISO 9241:210-2019)

Design approach to systems design and development that aims to make interactive systems more usable by focusing on the use of the system and applying human factors/ergonomics and usability knowledge and techniques

</section>

<section>

## UX design (from ISO 9241:210-2019)

Design to shape user’s perceptions and responses that result from the use and/or anticipated use of a system, product or service

</section>
<section>

## UI design (from ISO 9241:210-2019)

Design of all components of an interactive system (software or hardware) that provide information and controls for the user to accomplish specific tasks with the interactive system

</section>
<section>

## Service Design
	
Design of a system of people, processes, and products that is customized for user’s needs

</section>

content.title: Way of working
content.text:
## Two levels of way of working

<section>

### 1. Way of working between the UX design team and the Agile development team


![Uploading image.png]()
 
	 UX (informed by Design Thinking)	 Agile development

It is recommended that UX design stage precedes Agile development stage. In practice, the UX design stage is recommended to be carried out at two levels. One, at meta level where the information architecture (IA) of the solution is carried out and finalized in collaboration with the development team. At the same time, this stage of UX design also delivers detailed wireframes, including the behaviour of the interactive elements, that are evaluated with the intended users. Once this is finalised, it provides the vision for the development team. The development team then breaks down the vision in terms of epics, stories and sub tasks and prioritize them for development. Two, at micro level, where UX design team details out the wireframes – for the epic/story prioritised for development - and provides UI specifications for development. This stage of UX design works in parallel with development and provides continuous contribution as required by the epic/story. Once an epic/story is implemented and tested, the UX design team, moves on to the next sprint/development stage and repeats above mentioned tasks based on the epic/story. This continues until the end of the project.

</section>
<section>

### 2.The way of working within the UX team

UX team is, ideally, a multidisciplinary team with its members coming from a variety of disciplines, such as, design, computer science, graphic design, psychology, anthropology, sociology etc. It is not always the case that the UX design team will have this kind of diversity. At the same time, it is common for UX designers (through their education and experience) to have a good level of competence (originating from a variety of fields, such as sociology, design etc.) to run all aspects of the UX design process.

Given this, the UX design team should assess their competencies via a vis UX various stages of UX design process (such as, research, design, prototyping and evaluation) and assign responsibilities of conducting each such stages amongst themselves.

The UX design process, then, is carried out iteratively, in a sprint like fashion. That is, when the first cycle of UX design process constituting of research, design, prototyping and evaluation is complete and reflected upon (to access if the solution arrived at meets the needs of the intended users), another cycle of UX design process is carried out and the same is repeated until the solution arrived at addresses the needs of the intended users in the best possible manner and at an optimum cost.
![text](https://sdds-cms.s3.amazonaws.com/291242193267461c879afe8a5dd45277.png)

</section>

content.title: UI principles
content.text:
**Readability**

- Text to be read should have high contrast and adequate line spacing
- Choice of fonts and font sizes should be made with consideration of readability vis a vis size of the display 
- Test all designs on your oldest expected user population

**Discoverability**

- If the user cannot find it, it does not exist
- Use AD (Active Discovery) to guide people to more advanced features
- UI elements necessary for the successful use of product/solution should be visibly accessible at all times
- Communicate your gestural vocabulary with visual diagrams
- Strive for Balance
- User-test for discoverability

**Explorable Interfaces**

- Give users well-marked navigational structure
- Offer users stable perceptual cues for a sense of “home”
- Make Actions reversible or Always allow “Undo”
- Always allow a way out
- Make it easy and attractive to stay in

**Clarity**

Clarity is the one of the key features of a UI. As per Ben Shneiderman for an interface to be effective and user-friendly, it must be recognizable, predictable, and have an obvious purpose.

**State**

- As many of browser-based products/solutions exist in a stateless environment, tracking status must be designed in a suitable manner 
- Make clear to the user regarding the information that will stored & and that it will be protected

**Feedback**

- Provide timely and contextually-relevant feedback to the user.
- Feedback can be visual, auditory or haptic as required.

**Latency Reduction**

Keep users informed when they face delay

**Anticipation**

- Make visible to the user all UI elements needed for each step of the process

**Use of Metaphors**

- Choose metaphors that will enable users to comprehend the finest details of the conceptual model of the product/solution
- Must go beyond literal interpretation of real-world counterparts

**Human Interface Objects**

- Human-interface objects are easy to perceive and act upon
- Human-interface objects have a standard way of being manipulated
- Human-interface objects have standard resulting behaviours
- Use a new object when a new modality of interaction is introduced

**Purposeful page layout**

- Be judicious about the  spatial relationships between items on the page and structure the page based on importance. 

**Visible Navigation**

- Make navigation visible
- Limit number of navigation items by using overlays

**Colour**

*Colour blindness*

- When colour is used to convey information in the interface, use clear, secondary cues to convey the information to those who cannot see the colours presented.
- Test your site to see with colour blind users

*Colour as a vital interface element*

- User colour judiciously in UI 

**Fitts’s Law**

- The time to acquire a target is a function of the distance to and size of the target
- Fitts’s Law is in effect regardless of the kind of pointing device or the nature of the target
- Fitts’s Law requires a stop watch test

**Law of common region**

Elements tend to be perceived into groups if they located within a clearly defined boundary.

**Law of Proximity**

Objects that are proximate to each other tend to be grouped together.

**Miller’s Law**
The average person can only keep 7 (plus or minus 2) items in their working memory.


The Von Restorff effect, also known as The Isolation Effect, predicts that when multiple similar objects are present, the one that differs from the rest is most likely to be remembered.

content.title: UX principles
content.text:
**User/Human Centered Design**

User/Human-centered design is about creating products that will bring value to the users and the business. It is the users who will interact with the proposed product/solution, and it is the job of the designer to know the potential target audience. Designers must conduct user research to get a sense of user needs, wants, and behaviours as the first step of the design process.
At the same time, it is vital to Keep the user in control with updated system status, direct and effective UI manipulations, instant feedbacks and expectable interactions and outcomes.

**KISS (Keep It Simple Stupid)**

KISS is a fundamental user interface design principle. Users will feel most comfortable if they can use the product without putting in much efforts. 

**Autonomy**

Users perceive that they are always in control when interacting with the product/solution.

- Enable users to make their own decisions (e.g. with respect to navigation/interaction) when interacting with the product/solution
- Use status indicators to keep users aware and informed
- Keep status information up to date and easy to view and comprehend
- Ensure that status information is accurate

**Efficiency of the User**

- The efficiency in a product/solution is a result of the fundamental architecture of the system, not in the surface design of the interface
- User Error messages that help users in making sense of the status of the product/solution

**Aesthetics**

Users often perceive aesthetically pleasing design as design that’s more usable.

- Aesthetic design should be left to those schooled and skilled in its application: Graphic/visual designers
- Cosmetics should never trump usability
- Conduct user test the visual design as thoroughly as the behavioural design

**Simplicity**

- Use progressive revelation of the UI to flatten the learning curve
- Simplification does not mean elimination of necessary capabilities

**Learnability: take advantage of user’s familiarity**

- Jacob’s law - take advantages of user’s previous knowledge (existing mental models): Users spend most of their time on other sites. This means that users prefer your site to work the same way as all the other sites they already know.

**Consistency**
 
*A. Levels of Consistency*

Think of consistency at various levels. For example

1. Top level consistency
  - Platform consistency:  Consistent with guidelines and standards 
  - In-house consistency:  Consistent with look & feel across your products/services 
2. Consistency across a suite of products, e. g., Microsoft Office. General look & feel communicates across the family of a product/solution
3. The overall look & feel of a single app, application or service–splash screens, design elements, etc.
4. Small visible structures, such as icons, symbols, buttons, scroll bars, etc.
5. Invisible elements

Objects that convey information, rather than being used to generate information, should not be made invisible

*B. Induced Inconsistency*

- visual consistency should be tied up with behaviour of the UI elements. i.e., be visually consistent when UI elements behave in the same manner and inconsistent when UI elements behave differently.

*C. Consistency with User Expectation*

- Be consistent with expectations of the users of the product/solution

**Reduce short-term memory load (cognitive load)**

As human short term memory is only capable of retaining 5 to 7 items at a given time, make sure that this is incorporated judiciously into UI design.

**Forgiveness**

- Must ensure that users never lose their work – permit reversal of action
Error handling
- Any errors should be communicated in a human centred manner

content.title: Way of working
content.text:
## Two levels of way of working

<section>

### 1. Way of working between the UX design team and the Agile development team


![Uploading image.png]()
 
	 UX (informed by Design Thinking)	 Agile development

It is recommended that UX design stage precedes Agile development stage. In practice, the UX design stage is recommended to be carried out at two levels. One, at meta level where the information architecture (IA) of the solution is carried out and finalized in collaboration with the development team. At the same time, this stage of UX design also delivers detailed wireframes, including the behaviour of the interactive elements, that are evaluated with the intended users. Once this is finalised, it provides the vision for the development team. The development team then breaks down the vision in terms of epics, stories and sub tasks and prioritize them for development. Two, at micro level, where UX design team details out the wireframes – for the epic/story prioritised for development - and provides UI specifications for development. This stage of UX design works in parallel with development and provides continuous contribution as required by the epic/story. Once an epic/story is implemented and tested, the UX design team, moves on to the next sprint/development stage and repeats above mentioned tasks based on the epic/story. This continues until the end of the project.

</section>
<section>

### 2.The way of working within the UX team

UX team is, ideally, a multidisciplinary team with its members coming from a variety of disciplines, such as, design, computer science, graphic design, psychology, anthropology, sociology etc. It is not always the case that the UX design team will have this kind of diversity. At the same time, it is common for UX designers (through their education and experience) to have a good level of competence (originating from a variety of fields, such as sociology, design etc.) to run all aspects of the UX design process.

Given this, the UX design team should assess their competencies via a vis UX various stages of UX design process (such as, research, design, prototyping and evaluation) and assign responsibilities of conducting each such stages amongst themselves.

The UX design process, then, is carried out iteratively, in a sprint like fashion. That is, when the first cycle of UX design process constituting of research, design, prototyping and evaluation is complete and reflected upon (to access if the solution arrived at meets the needs of the intended users), another cycle of UX design process is carried out and the same is repeated until the solution arrived at addresses the needs of the intended users in the best possible manner and at an optimum cost.
![text](https://sdds-cms.s3.amazonaws.com/291242193267461c879afe8a5dd45277.png)

</section>

content.title: Alerts
content.text:
Alerts are banners/modals that communicate a message with a degree of urgency attached to it.

There are two key types of alerts: *standard alerts* and *application level alerts* Standard alerts are to be designed to garb user’s attention to provide critical information needed in a context of use.
**Standard Alerts** Standard alerts are of four types: *Success, Information, Warning and Error* **Usage Pattern: standard alerts**
__Success Alert__ - A banner/modal carries a message communicating to the user that the action taken by them have been successful. - The banner/modal carries a green encircled check mark to visually accentuate the success message. - The banner/modal itself should have a neutral colour (grey/white).
A simple success alert—check it out!
__Information Alert__ - The banner/modal carries a message communicating to the user that additional information is available about the context of use. - The banner/modal carries a black encircled exclamation mark to visually accentuate the success message. The banner/modal itself should have a neutral colour (grey/white).
A simple info alert—check it out!
__Warning alert__ - The banner/modal carries a message communicating to the user that the action taken by them have resulted in a warning with respect to the context of use. - The banner/modal carries a yellow outlined triangle with exclamation mark to visually accentuate the success message. The banner/modal itself should have a neutral colour (grey/white).
A simple warning alert—check it out!
__Error alert__ The banner/modal carries a message communicating to the user that the action taken by them have resulted in an error with respect to the context of use.
A simple danger alert—check it out!
The banner/modal carries red encircled cross mark to visually accentuate the success message. The banner/modal itself should have a neutral colour (grey/white). Standard alerts convey severity and urgency in the following order: error, warning, info and success. In case there are multiple subtypes (of each of the types mentioned above) all of them are shown before another standard alert type is shown. For example – multiple error warnings are shown before a warning alert is shown. Standard alerts could be place in multiple contexts including inside of components. **Application level alerts** Application level alerts are of three types: *Error, Warning and Information* **Usage Pattern: application level alerts** Application level alerts follow the same order as standard level alerts: Error, Warning and Information.

content.title: Badges
content.text:
Badges are used to highlight count (numerical value) associated with and item/event.

**Example** 2
**Usage Pattern** - Badges to have a colourful, bold and filled style to enable them to stand out when appearing within or next to a UI element. - Use integers with badges.

content.title: Badge Example
content.text: 2

content.title: Breadcrumbs
content.text:
Breadcrumbs are a navigational element to support wayfinding. It makes users of their current location (with respect to the application/website) and the option for further navigation. Breadcrumbs also show hierarchy of the navigation and allows users to navigate higher or lower in the hierarchy.

**Example**
  1. Home
  1. Home
  2. Library
  1. Home
  2. Library
  3. Data
**Usage Pattern** - Breadcrumbs should not replace global navigation or location navigation (in a section) but complement it. - Breadcrumbs should display the current location of the user with respect to hierarchy of navigational structure. - Breadcrumb corresponding the current page should not be a link. - Breadcrumbs are more useful for application/websites where the hierarchy if deeper than 2 levels. That is, it is not suitable for applications/sites that are have flat hierarchy. - Breadcrumb should start with link to home page.

content.title: Breadcrumbs Example
content.text:
1. Home
-
  1. Home
  2. Library
-
  1. Home
  2. Library
  3. Data

content.title: Button groups
content.text:
Buttons groups are collection of same type of buttons.

**Example**
Types of Button groups - Solid button group: meant for primary action, solid filled to attract user’s attention - Outline button group: meant for secondary action and to compliment primary action - Flat button group: meant for tertiary action - Disabled button group: meant to prevent users from sending inputs accidently, also meant to prevent input till conditions for the input are met.
**Usage Pattern** Button groups follow button design guidelines. Button groups can be constituted of the following:
**Mixed classes** ![text](https://sdds-cms.s3.amazonaws.com/a2cccee7a5614a3eb1bbc18d18452483.PNG) Mixing actions **Do** – Locate primary action on the left, followed by secondary and warning action. **Don’t** – Located warning action on the left.
![text](https://sdds-cms.s3.amazonaws.com/6818a75bf625462eb823f003161177d2.PNG) Mixing styles **Do**– group buttons that are styled in a similar manner – such as, primary and tertiary types **Don’t**– group button that are styles in a different manner – such as primary and secondary types
**Icons – width and spacing** ![text](https://sdds-cms.s3.amazonaws.com/24c96ddfa99d423281bf2a04341d8747.PNG)

Icons - Types and sizes

**Do**– Icons can be used with all types of buttons. However, make sure that the buttons are large size (36px) **Don’t** – use small size buttons with icons
**With text & icons** ![text](https://sdds-cms.s3.amazonaws.com/aa70aa1bae5542798493a3b4e83eb402.PNG) **Do**– text is useful with icons as they helps users. When used, icons should be followed by text **Don’t** – follow text by icons
**Overflow** To be used when the button group is larger than space available or there is intention to save space. In such cases, an ellipsis button is included in the button group that shows the overflow drop down menu. Interaction Clicking on ellipsis button will bring up a dropdown menu ![text](https://sdds-cms.s3.amazonaws.com/1ca911fc81dc452fa8ba4ec7b4aabb30.PNG) **Icons and Text** Follow the pattern of use of icons and text for buttons in this case. ![text](https://sdds-cms.s3.amazonaws.com/0183ac6194cb4cd6b558f26bd1e49086.PNG)
**Multiple groups** ![text](https://sdds-cms.s3.amazonaws.com/5997dc1f699a41ecbbd5f5a65668959e.PNG) **Do** – primary actions are followed by secondary action **Don’t** – secondary actions followed by primary action
**Checkbox** ![text](https://sdds-cms.s3.amazonaws.com/c8704217c8c94c64817ef15c2d7e43ff.PNG) **Do** – use short labels ( 1 to 3 words) **Don’t** – use labels that are longer than 3 words.
**Radio** ![text](https://sdds-cms.s3.amazonaws.com/61d3a3994ad5447ba954238302e58a9d.PNG) **Do** – use short labels ( 1 to 3 words) **Don’t** – use labels that are longer than 3 words.
